ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I really learned how to comprehensively study the skeletal system and appreciate the intricacies within it that contribute to why humans have biologically evolved the way we have.
Learn every bone in the body. You'll gain a deep appreciation for human anatomy and some topics in evolution, development, and bone biology.
Bones! I learned so much about bones.

I learned about literally every bone in the human skeleton as well as other key morphological features and muscle attachments. The hands-on approach by using the real human specimens in class is incredibly cool. And makes learning about these features all the more interesting.
So much about bones! Primarily how to distinguish every bone in the body (!) from the others, identify specific characteristics, and assign a side to them. Also general features of age, sex, etc.

I learned to identify every bone in the human body and soft tissue characteristics associated with some of them. I became more familiar with the entire human body and understood body mechanics a little better because I saw which muscles move which joints, etc. I learned to use contextual clues to identify certain specimens. I also learned how to handle human bone specimens with care.
I learned about all of the bones and many muscle attachments
Knowledge gained: Bone, bone structures, and bone attachment identification skills. Sexing and aging based on certain features. Bone development.
Bony anatomy of the human body
how to sex, age, and identity all the bones in the human body
All the bones in the body, and many of the bone features. Also, an intuitive understanding of bones useful in siding and sexing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Love that we get to learn at our own pace in a lab setting
This course is set up perfectly for what its goals are. The flipped-lab format allowed for deep engagement with the samples, of which Yale is rich in.

I really liked the flipped classroom style. I felt that we had the perfect amount of time for each unit (the upper limb really needed that extra day due to COVID). Dr. Sargis was very good about answering questions and providing you with the material you needed to succeed.
This is a great course. No suggestions  except it would be kind of entertaining if there was a true final where one had to assemble an entire human skeleton from its constituent bones.

Professor Sargis does warn you beforehand that this course has a flipped-classroom formatand that's not for everybody. I would be curious to see how this class would unfold if it were taught in a regular lecture class, or separated into a lecture and lab class. I think student would actually learn more that way. Or, split the class into two semesters and go more in depth into each module. Just that there's so much information and I think realistically we go through the material too fast. I really enjoyed the background lectures but we never got to explore the material further after the lecture itself which seemed like a waste.
I absolutely loved this course, I think the self-guided learning and the class setup works really well for the content

Strengths: So much hands-on lab time to touch real human bone samples and learn from them. The class is not very structured during lab time, so students can go at their own pace to learn all the content.
Weaknesses: The box of bones they give you for taking home is suuuper heavy to carry back.
Super fun! Lab sessions were enjoyable
a strong group environment, clear course organization, manageable workload, great instructors and ta

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely. The course content was incredible, especially for a STEM student, and made me appreciate the human body on a new level.
If you are interested in anatomy, absolutely. You'll have a great time and it will set you up for further study of anatomy in med school/grad school well.
Would absolutely recommend. Only thing is this is a very memorization heavy course so if that's not your thing, don't take it.

Yes! This course is truly incredible if you are at all interested in the human body. There is a lot of memorization that needs to go in before the quizzes/exams. I did fine on them but recommend taking this course Credit-D-Fail for maximum enjoyment.

As a senior, this class was truly one of the highlights of my Yale experience. While there is a lot of content you are responsible for, it is all a) very interesting and b) laid out very clearly. Prof. Sargis does an excellent job of making sure you know exactly what is required of you, and what is not. He also answers any and every question you have about the material in a clear, interesting, and fun way. The logical setup of the class means that there is very little stress  although the tests require lots of memorization, you know exactly what you have to memorize, and just showing up to class each day gets you >80% of the way there. Besides that, it is incredibly interesting to learn about human osteology, and even cooler to get an introduction to it by handling real human specimens. No other class can provide this kind of immersive experience into such a fascinating topic and get away with making it fun and stress-free.

I would recommend this to another student if you are (relatively) good at memorization and need a science gut. Pre-meds, this class is also for you to get a head start on the anatomy that you'll need to know anyway.
Yes, anyone interested in body anatomy or learning about bones and muscles
Yes! The class was super fun and something to look forward to.
Yes! Very fun bio lab requirement
absolutely- an especially great environment for students (from different academic backgrounds) to learn the human body

Yes I would. It's a great course. I don't know how to explain why other than it's awesome to learn about your body by using actual specimens. And to have this count as an Sc distributional requirement,, that's just great.
